Desktop 16GB Intel i7-3770 CPU & laptop 8GB Intel i5-2520M CPU Lenovo T420 (the desktop ran the performance test in 10m02s -- but the laptop was slightly faster at 9m40s) - all using the Mate Desktop Environment.

In the performance test, the laptop is more than 10 times slower than the desktop, whereas with 5.14.9 the laptop was slightly faster!

bugs.title: CVE-2021-3744 kernel: crypto: ccp - fix resource leaks in ccp_run_aes_gcm_cmd()

bugzilla.short_desc: CVE-2021-3744 kernel: crypto: ccp - fix resource leaks in ccp_run_aes_gcm_cmd()

long_desc.thetext:
A memory leak in the ccp_run_aes_gcm_cmd() function in drivers/crypto/ccp/ccp-ops.c in the Linux kernel allows attackers to cause a denial of service (memory consumption).

The patch for this one fixes:
1) If we ccp_init_data() fails for &src then we need to free aad.
   Use goto e_aad instead of goto e_ctx.
2) The label to free the &final_wa was named incorrectly as "e_tag" but
   it should have been "e_final_wa".  One error path leaked &final_wa.
3) The &tag was leaked on one error path.  In that case, I added a free
   before the goto because the resource was local to that block.

This vulnerability is similar with the older CVE-2019-18808.

Reference:
https://seclists.org/oss-sec/2021/q3/164

Created kernel tracking bugs for this issue:

Affects: fedora-all [bug 2009413]

the fixing upstream commit is present since v5.15-rc4 and is:
505d9dcb0f7d ("crypto: ccp - fix resource leaks in ccp_run_aes_gcm_cmd()")

This issue has been addressed in the following products:

  Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8

Via RHSA-2022:1975 https://access.redhat.com/errata/RHSA-2022:1975

This issue has been addressed in the following products:

  Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8

Via RHSA-2022:1988 https://access.redhat.com/errata/RHSA-2022:1988

This bug is now closed. Further updates for individual products will be reflected on the CVE page(s):

https://access.redhat.com/security/cve/cve-2021-3744

bugs.title: [Lenovo Fedora bug] Networking broken on T14 G2, T15 G2, X13 G2

bugzilla.short_desc: [Lenovo Fedora bug] Networking broken on T14 G2, T15 G2, X13 G2

long_desc.thetext:
Created attachment 1824780
Proposed patch from Intel

+++ This bug was initially created as a clone of Bug #1952803 +++

Description of problem: Wired networking is broken on any platform with the Intel networking device with PCI-ID 0x15FC (note - doesn't impact just Lenovo)

Once you suspend and resume throughput drops to just a few kbps, and there are large number or errored frames

Platform: Intel

Version-Release number of selected component (if applicable):

How reproducible: 100%

Steps to Reproduce:
1. transfer large file via wired ethernet port. e.g using scp
2. Check transfer rate. 
3. If transfer rate is decent (100Mbps) then suspend and resume and repeat

Actual results: Low transfer rate

Expected results: High transfer rate


Additional info:

I'll attach the candidate patch - which should be proposed upstream soon.

Notes from Intel (lightly edited for clarity):
Patch is a first candidate and is still under validation so please take it into consideration.
The root cause for the issue is as follows:
TGL introduced optimization in power management which shut down a clock that is required for exiting from K1 (K1 Is the equivalent of L1 for the proprietary PCIe like interface between the MAC and the PHY).
Due to missing configuration, this clock request was not asserted properly which caused a long K1 exit latency which is the reason for the performance issue.

Mark, I can submit a pull-req to get this patch added as a downstream patch to the Fedora kernels for now if you want me to, shall I do that ?

Also do you know if there has been any change in the upstreaming status of this?

Hi Hans,

I meant to update this bug - thanks for the nudge.

The upstream postings are here and should be used instead. There were some extra changes to make sure only Tigerlake PCH gets the change

https://patchwork.ozlabs.org/project/intel-wired-lan/patch/20210922065449.3780338-1-sasha.neftin@intel.com/
https://patchwork.ozlabs.org/project/intel-wired-lan/patch/20210922065542.3780389-1-sasha.neftin@intel.com/


I'll check with the patch owner - there were some minor comments from review but nothing functional impacting yet. I don't believe it's accepted yet.

I know Canonical decided to wait for the upstream to be confirmed before pulling this. There's been a bunch of testing both by ourselves and Canonical so it's looking promising but maybe hold off one week so we're confident on the upstream status before pulling this into Fedora.

Mark

Hi Hans,

Synced up with Sasha Neftin (Intel) on the patches. They are still under review but he doesn't foresee any issues. He pointed at these two commits in the next queue:
https://git.kernel.org/pub/scm/linux/kernel/git/tnguy/next-queue.git/commit/drivers/net/ethernet/intel/e1000e?h=dev-queue&id=08b633956e69b487bce0c30f7eb378e6551cd74a
https://git.kernel.org/pub/scm/linux/kernel/git/tnguy/next-queue.git/commit/drivers/net/ethernet/intel/e1000e?h=dev-queue&id=3b55b5183192f8e9f36760fdb9fc92c763c08498

As the ones to use as references. I think we should be good to go ahead with these - what do you think? Let me know if any concerns.

As a note - is this something I could/should submit a MR on kernel-ark for? I was just wondering how I can help contribute to Fedora for cases like this that are fairly small, simple and safe patches. Would like to get my team contributing more where possible...

Thanks :)
Mark

If you can submit a MR on kernel-ark for this yourself that would be great. That is exactly what was planning on doing myself.

You should submit a MR against the default os-build branch as well as a separate MR against the fedora-5.14 branch. This way once merged the fixes will show up in the rawhide 5.15-rc# builds (1) as well as in the current Fedora 33/34/35 5.14 kernel buidlds.

Drop me an email if you hit any issues with creating the MRs and need some help.

1) Which will eventually become Fedora 33/34/35 updates once 5.15 is stable
If you can submit the 5.14 one quickly, I can get it into the 5.14.10 build today, which will be the release kernel for F35 as well.

Thanks Justin,

I just finished testing os-build :) I don't think it will take me too long to get that wrapped up and switch to 5.14.10 - it would be awesome to get this in for F35

Mark

Two merge requests have gone in:
os-build: https://gitlab.com/cki-project/kernel-ark/-/merge_requests/1424
fedora5.14: https://gitlab.com/cki-project/kernel-ark/-/merge_requests/1425

Note - I noticed a typo in the title I made in the commits where I used e100e instead of e1000e. My apologies.

Let me know if there are any things I've got wrong or that can be improved. I'll document internally so others in the team can use for the future.

Thanks!
Mark

Fedora 35 Final blocker tracker bug: http://fedoraproject.org/wiki/BugZappers/HouseKeeping/Trackers

To propose a bug as blocking the Fedora 35 Final release, mark it as blocking this bug, or use the webapp: https://qa.fedoraproject.org/blockerbugs/propose_bug . It will be reviewed according to https://fedoraproject.org/wiki/QA:SOP_blocker_bug_process . If you can, please specify the release criterion that the bug violates. See https://fedoraproject.org/wiki/Fedora_Release_Criteria for details on the release criteria.

If the bug is not serious enough to block release but you believe it merits being fixed during a milestone freeze (see https://fedoraproject.org/wiki/Milestone_freezes ), you can propose it as a 'freeze exception' instead. To do this, mark it as blocking the bug F35FinalFreezeException . See https://fedoraproject.org/wiki/QA:SOP_freeze_exception_bug_process for the freeze exception process.

Sorry, I ran the wrong script...sigh.
Fedora 35 was released. Bug closed per https://fedoraproject.org/wiki/BugZappers/HouseKeeping/Trackers

1. Please describe the problem:

The Fedora kernel should default to device-tree on aarch64, and does with kernel-5.14.0-60.fc35.aarch64. Once upgraded to Kernel 5.14.1-300+ the default changes to ACPI.


2. What is the Version-Release number of the kernel:

Kernel 5.14.1-300+

Created attachment 1827042
5.14.0-60.fc35.aarch64 device-tree

Created attachment 1827043
5.14.1-300.fc35.aarch64 acpi default

Proposed as a Blocker for 35-final by Fedora user pbrobinson using the blocker tracking app because:

 The move to ACPI by defualt is a RHEL specific patch that shouldn't be applied to Fedora. In Fedora we use the upstream defaults because it causes us less issues because on a lot of devices that present both we want to use the upstream supported means.
Sorry I missed that one, patch reverted and will show up in 5.14.10+ kernels.

Discussed during the 2021-10-04 blocker review meeting: [1]

The decision to classify this bug as an AcceptedFreezeException (and to punt decision on blocker status) was made:

"We don't have a clear vote on whether this is serious enough to constitute a release blocker bug, but we definitely agree it's at least bad enough to grant a freeze exception, and expect the fix will land soon enough as to render the blocker question academic."

[1] https://meetbot-raw.fedoraproject.org/fedora-blocker-review/2021-10-04/f35-blocker-review.2021-10-04-16.02.log.html

The problem we have is that the ACPI tables may be quite different to the DT ones, and changing this in an upgrade can break the device because the initrd will be generate based on the current devices loaded/running where on reboot their may be different devices due to prioritising ACPI over DT and the user would end up with a non functional device.

This could affect a number of devices that have DT/ACPI firmware options, such as the RPi running EDK2, and the Jetson Xavier devices supported by Fedora IoT.

It's due to this which is why I believe it's a blocker.

Pasting the following from the blocker review app bug, because why would we have one location for the discussions:

So the reason I feel this is a blocker is that it affects the install media and can't fixed with an update. It can change how the HW looks so and in some cases what HW actually works and we're changing that experience and when run from the installer stuff may not work at all.

bugs.title: CVE-2021-3744 kernel: crypto: ccp - fix resource leaks in ccp_run_aes_gcm_cmd() [fedora-all]

bugzilla.short_desc: CVE-2021-3744 kernel: crypto: ccp - fix resource leaks in ccp_run_aes_gcm_cmd() [fedora-all]

blocked.short_desc: CVE-2021-3744 kernel: crypto: ccp - fix resource leaks in ccp_run_aes_gcm_cmd()

long_desc.thetext:
A memory leak in the ccp_run_aes_gcm_cmd() function in drivers/crypto/ccp/ccp-ops.c in the Linux kernel allows attackers to cause a denial of service (memory consumption).

The patch for this one fixes:
1) If we ccp_init_data() fails for &src then we need to free aad.
   Use goto e_aad instead of goto e_ctx.
2) The label to free the &final_wa was named incorrectly as "e_tag" but
   it should have been "e_final_wa".  One error path leaked &final_wa.
3) The &tag was leaked on one error path.  In that case, I added a free
   before the goto because the resource was local to that block.

This vulnerability is similar with the older CVE-2019-18808.

Reference:
https://seclists.org/oss-sec/2021/q3/164

Created kernel tracking bugs for this issue:

Affects: fedora-all [bug 2009413]

the fixing upstream commit is present since v5.15-rc4 and is:
505d9dcb0f7d ("crypto: ccp - fix resource leaks in ccp_run_aes_gcm_cmd()")

This issue has been addressed in the following products:

  Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8

Via RHSA-2022:1975 https://access.redhat.com/errata/RHSA-2022:1975

This issue has been addressed in the following products:

  Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8

Via RHSA-2022:1988 https://access.redhat.com/errata/RHSA-2022:1988

This bug is now closed. Further updates for individual products will be reflected on the CVE page(s):

https://access.redhat.com/security/cve/cve-2021-3744

This is an automatically created tracking bug!  It was created to ensure
that one or more security vulnerabilities are fixed in affected versions
of fedora-all.

For comments that are specific to the vulnerability please use bugs filed
against the "Security Response" product referenced in the "Blocks" field.

For more information see:
http://fedoraproject.org/wiki/Security/TrackingBugs

When submitting as an update, use the fedpkg template provided in the next
comment(s).  This will include the bug IDs of this tracking bug as well as
the relevant top-level CVE bugs.

Please also mention the CVE IDs being fixed in the RPM changelog and the
fedpkg commit message.

NOTE: this issue affects multiple supported versions of Fedora. While only
one tracking bug has been filed, please correct all affected versions at
the same time.  If you need to fix the versions independent of each other,
you may clone this bug as appropriate.

Reproducers, if any, will remain confidential and never be made public, unless done so by the security team.

Use the following template to for the 'fedpkg update' request to submit an
update for this issue as it contains the top-level parent bug(s) as well as
this tracking bug.  This will ensure that all associated bugs get updated
when new packages are pushed to stable.

=====

# bugfix, security, enhancement, newpackage (required)
type=security

# low, medium, high, urgent (required)
severity=medium

# testing, stable
request=testing

# Bug numbers: 1234,9876

# Description of your update
notes=Security fix for [PUT CVEs HERE]

# Enable request automation based on the stable/unstable karma thresholds
autokarma=True
stable_karma=3
unstable_karma=-3

# Automatically close bugs when this marked as stable
close_bugs=True

# Suggest that users restart after update
suggest_reboot=False

======

Additionally, you may opt to use the bodhi web interface to submit updates:

https://bodhi.fedoraproject.org/updates/new

If problem still persists, please make note of it in this bug report.

comment.text:
Desktop 16GB Intel i7-3770 CPU & laptop 8GB Intel i5-2520M CPU Lenovo T420 (the desktop ran the performance test in 10m02s -- but the laptop was slightly faster at 9m40s) - all using the Mate Desktop Environment.

In the performance test, the laptop is more than 10 times slower than the desktop, whereas with 5.14.9 the laptop was slightly faster!
@jforbes The laptop should not be taking more than 10 times the elapsed time of the desktop to do the performance test, as on last kernel version it is actually slightly quicker by a few seconds!
No issues, returns aarch64 default to device-tree.
No issues, returns aarch64 default to device-tree.
It boot on I5 5200U primary GPU nvidia - driver version installed 470.74
Default & performance tests pass (KVM)
@nivag Reading your comment, I don't understand why the negative karma.  Was there a problem you ran into?

Works for me, it's been up for quite a few hours now..  
The enabled Default and Performance tests pass OK. AMD 965, x86_64 work station, SSD's > RAID1. Plasma DE from Zawertun's COPR, X-org, nVidia GT 1030 using nVidia RPM's from RPMFusion (470.74)
Default & performance tests pass (KVM)

Runnig here for some hours by now,  it looks fine.
Processors: 8 × Intel® Core™ i7-3632QM CPU @ 2.20GHz
Memory: 15.4 GiB of RAM
Graphics Processor: Mesa Intel® HD Graphics 4000
LGTM. No regressions noted.
very loud sound on gdm start, during login to GNOME and after logging (no applications using sound were running).
Default & performance tests pass (KVM)

bugs.title: CVE-2021-41864 kernel: eBPF multiplication integer overflow in prealloc_elems_and_freelist() in kernel/bpf/stackmap.c leads to out-of-bounds write

bugzilla.short_desc: CVE-2021-41864 kernel: eBPF multiplication integer overflow in prealloc_elems_and_freelist() in kernel/bpf/stackmap.c leads to out-of-bounds write

long_desc.thetext:
An out-of-bounds (OOB) memory write flaw was found in prealloc_elems_and_freelist in  kernel/bpf/stackmap.c in the bpf iin the Linux kernel. In this flaw, the multiplication to calculate the size could lead to an integer overflow, and this could allow a local attacker, with a special user privilege to gain access to out-of-bounds memory leading to a system crash or a leak of internal kernel information.

Reference and upstream patch:
https://github.com/torvalds/linux/commit/30e29a9a2bc6a4888335a6ede968b75cd329657a

Created kernel tracking bugs for this issue:

Affects: fedora-all [bug 2010464]

This issue has been addressed in the following products:

  Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8

Via RHSA-2022:1975 https://access.redhat.com/errata/RHSA-2022:1975

This issue has been addressed in the following products:

  Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8

Via RHSA-2022:1988 https://access.redhat.com/errata/RHSA-2022:1988

This bug is now closed. Further updates for individual products will be reflected on the CVE page(s):

https://access.redhat.com/security/cve/cve-2021-41864

This is an automatically created tracking bug!  It was created to ensure
that one or more security vulnerabilities are fixed in affected versions
of fedora-all.

For comments that are specific to the vulnerability please use bugs filed
against the "Security Response" product referenced in the "Blocks" field.

For more information see:
http://fedoraproject.org/wiki/Security/TrackingBugs

When submitting as an update, use the fedpkg template provided in the next
comment(s).  This will include the bug IDs of this tracking bug as well as
the relevant top-level CVE bugs.

Please also mention the CVE IDs being fixed in the RPM changelog and the
fedpkg commit message.

NOTE: this issue affects multiple supported versions of Fedora. While only
one tracking bug has been filed, please correct all affected versions at
the same time.  If you need to fix the versions independent of each other,
you may clone this bug as appropriate.

Reproducers, if any, will remain confidential and never be made public, unless done so by the security team.

Use the following template to for the 'fedpkg update' request to submit an
update for this issue as it contains the top-level parent bug(s) as well as
this tracking bug.  This will ensure that all associated bugs get updated
when new packages are pushed to stable.

=====

# bugfix, security, enhancement, newpackage (required)
type=security

# low, medium, high, urgent (required)
severity=high

# testing, stable
request=testing

# Bug numbers: 1234,9876
bugs=2010463,2010464

# Description of your update
notes=Security fix for [PUT CVEs HERE]

# Enable request automation based on the stable/unstable karma thresholds
autokarma=True
stable_karma=3
unstable_karma=-3

# Automatically close bugs when this marked as stable
close_bugs=True

# Suggest that users restart after update
suggest_reboot=False

======

Additionally, you may opt to use the bodhi web interface to submit updates:

https://bodhi.fedoraproject.org/updates/new
